01-Caroline-College/03-The-College/02-Pe.title: Dr. Daniel J. Stanton
01-Caroline-College/03-The-College/02-Pe.content:
Dr. Daniel J. Stanton
President, Caroline College
Class of 1937

Dr. Daniel J. Stanton has been the president of Caroline College since 1974. A proud alumnus, Dr. Stanton returned to his alma mater to lead the college into a new era of growth and innovation. Under his leadership, Caroline College has expanded its programs, modernized its facilities, and strengthened its ties with the local community. His contributions to the college’s advancements include the development of the Philip Love Aquatic Center.
Dr. Stanton earned his doctorate in internal business affairs, building on his successful career in international trade and commerce. He holds and honorary doctorate in education from a major university in Massachusetts.  After World War II, he established a thriving import business, focusing on Asian markets, which supported post-war economic recovery efforts. Through his business acumen, Dr. Stanton has made significant contributions to both the educational and business worlds, and his leadership has helped Caroline College rise to new heights.
Known for his charismatic leadership style and business expertise, Dr. Stanton is a vocal proponent of small government, believing in the power of private enterprise and individual initiative. His commitment to both the college and the greater Watashuka community reflects his deep sense of duty and dedication to education.

01-Caroline-College/03-The-College/02-Pe.title: Professor Katherine Coates
01-Caroline-College/03-The-College/02-Pe.content:
Professor Katherine Coates
In a cluttered office filled with stacks of newspapers and journalism textbooks, a woman is angry; very angry. She sits at her desk, tapping her pencil against a file of student stories. Her short, curly hair bounces slightly as she leans forward to read an article submission more closely. "This needs more depth," she mutters to herself before scribbling notes in the margins. She pushes her glasses up the bridge of her nose and looks out the window. She is fuming. She's going to reject this article for the Crier. She knows it. She also knows its wrong. "Not enough reference material. No interviews. Topic is not worth exploring further." Stacy is a good student and she'll be hurt that her article was rejected for unfair reasons but she'll get over it. She'll rise above it.
Coates puts the marked up document in her out box. The title "What Happens On Campus After Midnight?" can be seen sticking out. The professor turns on the campus radio and calms down. "College Chaos". Right show, right time. No interruptions.
Role/Title:
Head of the Journalism Department at Caroline College, Faculty Advisor for The Crier (student newspaper)
Description:
Professor Katherine Coates is the head of the Journalism Department at Caroline College, where she teaches investigative journalism and ethics. Known for her no-nonsense approach to journalism, Katherine is deeply passionate about the role of the press in society and its potential to expose corruption and inspire change. Her idealism and dedication to journalistic integrity make her a well-respected figure among students, though some find her methods rigid. Katherine also serves as the faculty advisor for The Crier, the college’s student-run newspaper, where she pushes students to dig deeper and challenge the status quo.

01-Caroline-College/03-The-College/02-Pe.title: Michelina Plum
01-Caroline-College/03-The-College/02-Pe.content:
Michelina Plum


Age: 36 (in 1983)


Role: Michelina Plum is the sultry host of Night Vibes, a late-night radio show on WCTU, Watashuka’s college radio station. Her program, running from 10:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m., features soothing instrumental music and classical tracks aimed at helping her listeners relax during the long, quiet hours of the night. Michelina’s smooth, calming voice has earned her a dedicated following, particularly among students and night-shift workers.


Appearance: Michelina is an attractive woman with striking red hair that falls in loose waves around her shoulders. She has sharp features and bright green eyes that stand out against her glamorous, if somewhat disheveled, appearance. Often dressed in silky, low-cut blouses, she exudes an air of confidence and mystery, especially when she’s behind the microphone. On air, Michelina’s polished, professional persona is in contrast to the sharp, more intense side of her character that only those close to her see.


Personality: On the radio, Michelina is known for her calm, reassuring tone, a voice that seems to ease the worries of her late-night listeners. Off-air, however, she is a different person entirely—witty, foul-mouthed, and with a sharp sense of humor. Michelina is highly political, frequently expressing her admiration for President Reagan and her disdain for the local counterculture.


Public Role:

WCTU Radio Host: Michelina is well-known in the community for her late-night radio show, which provides a soothing soundtrack to the town’s quieter hours. She is regarded as an intellectual and a voice of reason, offering a space for Watashuka’s insomniacs, students, and night workers to find comfort in the music she plays.
Mothers Opposing Metal (MOM): Michelina is a vocal member of Mothers Opposing Metal, a conservative group that fights against the influence of heavy metal music and other perceived corruptions of youth. She frequently speaks out against the local pirate radio DJ, Dave, and the Metalheads, blaming them for the town’s moral decline.



Public Perception: Most people in Watashuka see Michelina as a respected, conservative figure who upholds traditional values and provides a calming presence through her radio show. She is known for her intelligence and her involvement in MOM, which reinforces her image as a defender of the town’s moral standards. Her sharp political views and vocal support for Reagan resonate with many of the town’s conservative residents, though there are whispers about her hidden wild side from those who know her better.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/00-Info.title: History of Watashuka
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/00-Info.content:
History of Watashuka

May 1856 – Founding of Prairieville Academy

Prairieville Academy is established as a teacher-training school (normal school) to educate future educators. The academy becomes the heart of the town of Prairieville, which later becomes Watashuka. The academy was the dream of three educators Walter Mann, Eleazar Root and John W. Sterling. There dream was to work with the local Ho-Chunk people to bring forth a new era for the region. That dream is still alive today despite setbacks.
Founding Members

Walter Mann: German immigrant, artist, head founder of the academy
Eleazar Root: Co-founder. Massachusetts school teacher, relocated
John W. Sterling: Co-founder, English businessman, relocated
Elias Haskins: Co-founder, local prominent cavalrymen
Jonathan Whitmore: Co-founder, local esteemed teacher and theologian
Sarah Johnson: Co-founder, local wealthy widow and philanthropist




August 1860 – Destruction of Prairieville Academy

The academy is destroyed during a violent conflict between the settlers and a rogue native tribe who attacked the school. During the attack many of the educators and founders were killed; only Eleazar Root and John Sterling survived. The academy burned down. Many blame local tensions with indigenous people on the attack. Most records from this time are lost, and it remains a tragic, but poorly understood, event in local history.


September 1862 – Rebuilding of Prairieville School

In the wake of the academy’s destruction, the Prairieville School is built to continue the region’s educational mission. Under the leadership of Eleazar Root and John W. Sterling the school thrives and grows as part of the effort to revitalize education in the region, attracting settlers to the area. Eleazar served as the school's first principal while John provided the financial and political support.


Blizzard of 1888 - Humanitarian Aid

After the Blizzard of 1888, large numbers of members of the Lutheran Church immigrate to the region. The first settlers arrive to provide humanitarian assistance but soon took to calling the region home.


April 1895 – Caroline Religious Teaching College Founded

Due to the influence of Lutheran immigrants, the Caroline Religious Teaching College is established, expanding the former school into a larger institution focused on religious education. This school subsumed the Prairieville School and most agree that this was more of a renaming than a new school.
At the same time, the town of Prairieville is renamed Watashuka out of respect of the native peoples.

A minor controversy emerged years later when it was found that name was a wild misinterpreted of the Ho-Chunk language. The intend was to have the name mean friendship or unity; symbolizing the area's different cultural influences. By the time the mistake was found the name had stuck.




1939-1945 – World War II Efforts

Caroline Religious Teaching College contributes to the war effort, with local industry and students engaging in patriotic duties. The college’s science and engineering departments grow due to wartime funding. After the war, the college continues expanding its academic programs.


1943 – Caroline College Renamed

The college is officially renamed Caroline College after WWII, reflecting its role as a modern liberal arts institution. The post-war years brought growth and new facilities, including Sister Sarah’s Medical Center, a teaching hospital for nursing and healthcare students.


1969 – Population Decline

Watashuka’s population begins to decline in the late 1960s due to changing economic conditions; notably the closing of several government projects now deemed complete. People start leaving for larger cities like Madison and Milwaukee. The closing of some industries and the general economic downturn are seen as the reasons for this decline.
The Watashuka Initiative's ending dealt a major blow to the region.


1983-Present – Present Day Watashuka

Watashuka is a quiet rural town with Caroline College as its centerpiece. The town struggles economically, but the college brings new students and some level of vibrancy. Residents are largely unaware of any significant issues beyond normal small-town troubles.

Town of Watashuka Directory

{Feel: Small-town America, where even those better off economically are still considered disadvantaged by the standards of most of the country.}
Main Street

The Press Newsstand

Owner: Margaret "Marge" Wilkins, a no-nonsense woman in her late 50s.
Description: Located on Main Street, The Press Newsstand has been a fixture in Watashuka for decades. Marge, the gruff but friendly owner, runs the small shop, which offers everything from local newspapers and national magazines to candy and cigarettes. Though small, the newsstand sees plenty of foot traffic, especially from old-timers and curious teenagers who like to pick up the latest gossip. Marge has a sharp eye for detail and always seems to know what’s going on in town.


The Prairie Press

Owner: Norm Habersham
Established: 1932
Description: The Prairie Press is the town’s local newspaper, and Norm has been its senior editor for over 30 years. The building is a modest, single-story office with a big front window displaying the latest headlines. Norm’s dedication to local journalism keeps the small office buzzing with activity despite the declining readership.


Frozen Cow Burger Stand

Owner: Mike and Ruth Garrison
Description: Mike and Ruth run this nostalgic 1950s-style burger stand. The small, red-and-white building is a summertime favorite, offering burgers, shakes, and fries to locals and tourists. But even during winter months, the place stays hopping thanks to students from Caroline College. Mike is the talkative type, while Ruth ensures everything in the kitchen runs smoothly. They frequently hire local high school and college students to help meet customers who have been known to line up out the door.


The Prince: New & Used Books

Owner: Dexter Colby
Description: A charming, slightly dusty bookstore filled with a carefully curated selection of new and used books. The Prince, often misidentified by students as 'The Prints', is known for its quiet, cozy atmosphere, with shelves that seem to go on forever. Dexter Colby, the reserved and knowledgeable owner, has been running the shop for as long as anyone can remember. He has a reputation for always being able to find rare or hard-to-find books, making The Prince a favorite spot for local book lovers and collectors alike. The store’s resident cat, Poe, is often found napping in a sunbeam near the front window.


Creek Music Store

Owner: Tom Creek
Description: A small, cramped store filled with violins, horns, guitars, records, and old music equipment. Tom is a gruff, middle-aged musician who loves to chat about the glory days of rock and roll. The store's walls are covered with band posters from decades past.


Diane's VCR/TV/Typewriter Sales, Service and Movie Rental

Owner: Diane Forrester
Description: Diane’s shop is a catch-all for aging electronics, VCR rentals, and typewriter repairs. The cluttered storefront is an intimidating mess, but Diane’s expertise keeps her loyal customers coming back. She’s known to be friendly, but a bit of a technophobe when it comes to modern computers.


Dance With Us! Studios

Owner: Beth Carmichael
Description: Beth runs this small dance studio with passion, teaching ballet, jazz, and tap to children and adults alike. The building is an old converted warehouse with wooden floors and mirrored walls. Beth is energetic and upbeat, always encouraging her students to do their best.


The Hut (Electronics And Appliance)

Owner: Jerry "Buzz" Horton
Description: The Hut is a compact store crammed with everything from radios to refrigerators. Buzz is a gadget enthusiast and knows every feature of the appliances he sells. The store’s slightly disorganized appearance reflects Buzz’s chaotic but friendly personality.


Watashuka Public Services Building (City Hall, Courthouse, jail, police, fire)

Owner: Public Services
Description: This imposing brick building serves as the town’s administrative hub. It’s home to the town’s municipal government, police, fire station, and courthouse. The staff is small but efficient, handling everything from zoning permits to civil disputes.


Watashuka Post Office

Owner: U.S. Postal Service (Postmaster: Linda Neal)
Description: The post office is a simple, utilitarian building with a friendly atmosphere. Linda Neal, the town’s long-serving postmaster, oversees a small team who know most customers by name. The building also serves as a gathering spot for older residents picking up their mail.


Bergmann’s Drugstore

Owner: Henry Bergmann
Description: A classic, small-town drugstore with a soda fountain counter that harks back to the 1950s. Henry is a kindly older man who has run the pharmacy for over 40 years. His gentle demeanor makes him a favorite among locals, who rely on his store for medications and sundries.


Albert’s General Goods

Owner: Albert “Al” Ralston
Description: A catch-all general store selling everything from canned food to gardening tools. Al is a no-nonsense man in his 50s with a gruff exterior but a heart of gold. The store is packed with shelves of goods, and Al seems to know where everything is in his well-worn shop. 



Downtown Side Streets and Alleys

Hanson's Hardware & Building Supplies (Closed, relocated)
Freeman & Burke Attorneys at Law

Owner: Sarah Freeman and Michael Burke
Description: A small general practice law firm specializing in family law, real estate, and business contracts. Sarah and Michael are both serious and professional but maintain a friendly rapport with their clients. Their office is located in a charming converted house on a side street near the town center.


Fixer’s Supply Co.

Owner: Roy and Jean Fixer
Description: Roy and Jean run this well-stocked hardware and building supply store. Known for their friendly service and practical advice, the couple has made Fixer’s a go-to spot for home improvement supplies. The large building on a side street still has an old-school charm, with its wood-paneled walls and hand-painted signage.


Blue Heron Pub & Grill

Owner: Paul Erickson
Description: A classic pub with a comfortable, lived-in feel. The Blue Heron serves as a gathering place for locals, offering simple but tasty pub food. Paul is a laid-back owner who enjoys a good conversation with his patrons, often sitting at the bar during slow hours.


Local Savings & Loan

Description: The oldest financial institution in town, Local Savings & Loan has provided banking services to residents for generations. The building is an imposing 1930s structure located off Main Street.


Watashuka Fitness & Recreation Center

Owner: Jenny and Todd Mills
Description: A modest fitness center with an attached community gym. Jenny and Todd are fitness enthusiasts who returned to Watashuka after college to open the center. They host fitness classes and recreational leagues for the town’s youth.


SmileWorks Dental Care

Owner: Dr. Ellie Chambers
Description: A cheerful dental office with bright, kid-friendly décor. Dr. Ellie is a warm and caring dentist who returned to her hometown after dental school. The small building offers basic dental services with a personal touch.


Eyes on Watashuka Optometry

Owner: Dr. Michael Larson
Description: A small, neat optometry office where Dr. Larson provides eye exams and glasses. He is soft-spoken but knowledgeable, making him a trusted figure in the community. The office has a quiet, calming atmosphere, with vintage eyeglass frames displayed as décor.


Spin Cycle Laundry & Dry Cleaners

Owner: Margaret and Earl Jacobs
Description: A family-run laundromat with attached dry cleaning services. Margaret manages the dry cleaning side, while Earl runs the laundromat. The building is a little worn, but it’s a reliable place where locals come to clean their clothes or chat while waiting for the spin cycle to end.


The Stand: Community Theatre

Owner: Watashuka Theatre Group (Managed by Mary Cline)
Description: A charming little community theater housed in a renovated church. Mary Cline is the passionate director of the theater group, which puts on performances throughout the year. The space is intimate, with just enough room for an enthusiastic crowd.


Frontier Life History Center

Owner: Watashuka Historical Society (Curator: Alan Graves)
Description: A small museum dedicated to Watashuka’s pioneer history. Alan Graves, the curator, is an eccentric historian who loves sharing stories of the town’s early days. The building itself is an old cabin-like structure, restored to give visitors a sense of what life was like in the past.


Watashuka WP (Water and Power)

Description: A functional, no-nonsense utility building where the town’s water and power systems are managed. The employees are friendly but busy, ensuring that the town’s essential services run smoothly without interruption.


All Saints Church of Watashuka (Lutheran Church)

Built: 1897
Head: Pastor Daniel Mueller
Description: A modest but well-maintained Lutheran church with a tall steeple. Pastor Mueller is a kind and soft-spoken man who has served the congregation for over a decade. The church is a cornerstone of the community, hosting services, events, and local outreach programs.


Bakers' Creamery & Bakery

Owners: Clint and Amanda Baker
Description: Located just off Main Street, this neighborhood grocery is known for its fresh-baked bread and local dairy products. Bakers' is a quiet spot where locals often run into one another after church for ice cream or cookies.


Prairie Realty

Owner: Jim Halushka
Description: A local real estate office handling everything from farmland to residential properties. Prairie Realty has deep roots in Watashuka and plays a key role in selling historic homes and new development areas.


River’s End Funeral Services

Owner: The Hansen Family
Description: A family-run establishment that provides personalized funeral services. Known for its caring staff and beautifully maintained grounds just outside the town center.


Petals & Posies

Owner: Stanley Romano
Description: A quaint little flower shop nestled on one of the side streets off Main. Petals & Posies is beloved for its affordable, custom flower arrangements and its personal touch for every event.


Which In The Wardrobe

Owner: Rebecca Covell
Description: A charming boutique offering affordable clothing and accessories for women and men. It's a place where locals can find everything from casual wear to outfits for special occasions.
 



Atmosphere:

Watashuka’s Main Street is the lifeblood of the town, though it has seen better days. Lined with small businesses and family-owned shops, it exudes a nostalgic charm. During the day, it bustles with locals running errands and small talk flowing between shopkeepers and customers. The sounds of typewriters, local radio, and the clinking of glasses at the Blue Heron Pub fill the air. However, as the sun sets, Main Street takes on a different tone. Shadows seem to stretch longer here, and the empty streets echo with an eerie silence. The old brick buildings, now weathered and fading, whisper of past prosperity, but there’s a creeping unease.
The side streets add to the town’s atmosphere of quiet decay, with narrow, cobbled roads leading to forgotten businesses like old law firms and shuttered hardware stores. These roads seem darker at night, and there’s a sense that they have stories of their own.

Northwest "Sterling Hills"
 {Notes: State Route 89 marks the town's western border}
 {Feel: Mostly affluent, not wealthy, but doing better than the rest of the town.}

North High School

Principal: Mr. Peter Clarke, a stern but fair educator who has been principal for over a decade.
Description: As the only remaining high school in Watashuka, North High School is vital to the town’s educational system. The building is old, with some sections dating back to the 1950s, but it's well-maintained thanks to Principal Clarke's efforts. The mysterious destruction of South High School years ago in a boiler explosion haunts the faculty, with rumors still swirling about whether it was an accident or spiteful former students.


Jack's Surfer: Comics & Games

Owner: Jack Hastings, an eccentric man in his 40s with a deep love for comics, tabletop role-playing games, and 80s pop culture.
Description: Jack’s store is a haven for local teenagers and college students. Its walls are lined with comic books, old action figures, and game paraphernalia. Jack often hosts Dungeons & Dragons nights and has a hidden stash of rare comics and RPG sourcebooks for special customers. The store has a loyal following among the town’s youth, particularly those interested in metal music and counterculture, making it a target for the "Mothers Opposing Metal" group.


Linda’s Beauty & Hair Salon

Owner: Linda Novak, a no-nonsense hairdresser in her late 50s who has been cutting hair in Watashuka for as long as anyone can remember.
Description: The salon is a small, cozy space with a few chairs, and Linda prides herself on knowing everyone's business. It’s where gossip spreads, and rumors about the oddities in Watashuka often start or grow here. Linda is friendly but doesn’t shy away from offering her opinion on anything. Her clients trust her judgment, making her an informal source of local news.


Watashuka Bus Depot

Manager: Frank Holloway, a quiet, middle-aged man who has worked at the depot for over 20 years.
Description: The bus depot is a small, utilitarian building that serves as a hub for both passengers and cargo deliveries. The depot connects Watashuka to nearby cities, but the service has seen a decline over the years due to the shrinking population.


Homes of Caroline College Faculty and Staff

Residents: Various faculty and staff members from Caroline College, with a mix of younger professionals and older professors who have lived in Watashuka for decades.
Description: The homes in this area are modest but well-kept, mostly occupied by college faculty who commute to the campus. The homes here are older, with a sense of quiet respectability, but at night, the streets can feel eerie, as though those that stroll the quiet streets are always being watched.


Homes of Government Staff

Residents: Various staff connected to Project Caroline and other secretive government initiatives.
Description: On the surface, these homes seem perfectly ordinary, blending in with the rest of the northwest. However, these government workers are often more reclusive, keeping their personal lives secret due to work regulations. It's not uncommon for new families to move in suddenly without much introduction, and neighbors have learned not to ask too many questions.



Outside of the town limits to the Northwest

Caroline College

Atmosphere

Sterling Hills is a peaceful and affluent part of Watashuka, home to Caroline College faculty, government staff, and some of the town’s more well-off residents. The streets are lined with mature trees and stately homes, giving the neighborhood an air of quiet respectability. On the surface, Sterling Hills feels safe and orderly, but there’s an underlying tension among the residents, particularly those with ties to the college or government projects.
Caroline College’s campus stands apart from the town of Watashuka, its stately buildings and green lawns giving it an air of academia and history. A distance of several miles, through dense woods, separate the school from its town.

Northeast "Farmer's Ridge"
 {Feel: Very rural, farm focused} 

Hanson’s Hardware & Building Supplies (Relocated from Downtown)

Owner: Jack Hanson
Description: After closing the downtown location, Jack Hanson moved his hardware store to the northeast of town, closer to the rural community it serves. Jack is a gruff but helpful man, always willing to offer advice on home repairs and farming tools.


Watashuka Co-Op Farming Supplies

Owner: Co-Operative (Manager: Fred Yoder)
Description: A bustling co-op that provides farming supplies to local dairy farmers and crop growers. Fred Yoder, a practical man with deep roots in the Amish community, manages the co-op. The building is large and utilitarian, but always busy.


Yoder’s Amish Goods Market

Owner: The Yoder Family
Description: A rustic market selling handmade Amish goods, including baked items, furniture, and crafts. The Yoders are a quiet but friendly family, well-known for their traditional methods and quality products. The market is a charming wooden structure with a welcoming atmosphere.



Outside of the town limits to the Northeast

Amish Community Border
Watashuka Farmers

Atmosphere

Farmer’s Ridge is the agricultural heart of Watashuka, where life revolves around the seasons, livestock, and the land. The area feels timeless, with endless rows of crops and farmhouses dotting the landscape. There’s a peacefulness here, but also a sense of isolation. The farmers are proud and self-reliant. The Amish community nearby maintains a watchful eye while keeping their deeper knowledge to themselves.
The Amish lands to the northeast of Watashuka are serene and picturesque, with rolling hills, wide fields, and carefully maintained farms that seem untouched by time. Horse-drawn buggies travel along dirt roads, and the simple wooden homes and barns give the area a peaceful, pastoral quality. The air smells of fresh-cut hay and wood smoke, and the rhythmic sound of hammering and livestock creates a sense of calm industry. Life here feels slower and more purposeful, far removed from the chaos that pervades the rest of the town.

Southwest "Prairieview Downs"
 {Notes: Corner of State Route 89 and State Route 11 marks the town boarder} {Notes: Boarder of Ho-Chunk native people's land (further to the south west)} {Feel: Very rural, keep to themselves type people} 

K Squared Gas Station

Owner: Kevin and Kyle Kilgore, twin brothers who run the station.
Description: Located on the way out of town, heading towards Caroline College, K Squared is more than just a rural gas station. It serves as a morning pit stop for students and faculty on their way to class. In addition to fuel, the store offers coffee, breakfast snacks, and basic supplies. The Kilgore brothers are known for their friendly banter and keeping tabs on the local happenings.


Annie's Animal and Game Processing Plant

Owner: Annette "Annie" Martin, a tough, no-nonsense woman in her early 60s.
Description: Annie’s processing plant serves the rural hunting and farming communities around Watashuka. She processes everything from livestock to wild game for local farmers and hunters. The plant, located just off State Route 89, is a sprawling complex that smells of blood and meat. Annie has worked here her whole life.


Streamwader's Hunting Goods

Owner: Jim Watson, a grizzled Vietnam War vet and experienced outdoorsman.
Description: Streamwader’s shop is a small, rugged building filled with hunting rifles, bows, traps, and other outdoor equipment. Jim has lived in Watashuka for decades and loves to share his stories with the younger generation of hunters, though his more chilling tales are often dismissed as the ramblings of an old soldier.


Rural Communities

Residents: Dairy farmers, crop growers, and livestock ranchers.
Description: The sprawling farmland to the southwest is home to families who have lived in Watashuka for generations. These farmers are mostly self-sufficient, and many have an unspoken rule to mind their own business.


Ho-Chunk Information Center

Curator: Mary Whitecloud, a knowledgeable and reserved Ho-Chunk woman in her late 40s.
Description: This small center serves as an educational hub about the Ho-Chunk people, their history, and their culture. The building is humble but welcoming, with displays about Ho-Chunk traditions and artifacts. Mary runs the center, offering tours and answering questions from visitors.



Outside of the town limits to the Southwest

The Wet Spot

Owner: “Big” Tony D’Amato, a business-savvy man in his 50s.
Description: Despite its seedy reputation, The Wet Spot is a popular hangout for college students, known for cheap drinks and live music. The club, located just outside town limits near Lake Mary. Tony, the owner, loves catering to the college crowd, offering student discounts and hosting wild theme nights. Locals mostly avoid the place, but for Caroline College students, it’s a spot to unwind away from prying eyes. Though rumors swirl about shady dealings, Tony keeps a tight lid on any trouble, preferring to keep things legal—and profitable.


Border of Ho-Chunk Native People's Lands

Atmosphere

The Downs are a mix of sprawling farmlands and quiet, isolated properties. The air is thick with the smell of fresh hay and the sound of distant tractors, creating a rural, down-to-earth feel. It’s a hard-working community where people keep to themselves and don't ask too many questions.
The Ho-Chunk lands are sacred and revered, with a strong connection to the spiritual. The area is quiet, peaceful, and somewhat eerie. The trees here seem older, and the wind carries with it the weight of ancient history. Many in Watashuka avoid this part of the land.

South East "Lakeview"
 {Feel: Working Class mixes with impoverished housing and abandoned lots}
 {Note: You cannot see the lake from the neighborhood.}

Lakeview Elementary And Jr. High School

Owner/Principal: Principal Nancy Doyle, a stern yet caring woman who has run the school for over 20 years, is known for her no-nonsense attitude.
Description: The school serves the local working-class families of Watashuka. It's an aging building, with outdated facilities, but a dedicated staff. Known for its tight-knit community, teachers often go above and beyond to help students who face difficult circumstances at home.


Mackie Recreational Park

Caretaker: Gary “Old Man” Dutton, a retiree who volunteers his time to maintain the park, always seen with his trusty rake in hand.
Description: Once a bustling park for families, Mackie Recreational Park now has overgrown fields and outdated playground equipment. Despite its wear, it’s a gathering place for children after school and hosts occasional community events.


Berg Farm House

Owner: Unknown and in dispute. The Watashuka Historical Society is attempting to take ownership but they lack the funds.
Description: The oldest surviving building in the region, the Berg Farm House was built before 1876. This is known from a surviving watercolor painting dated from 1876. It is suspected that the structure may have an older origin. The building is currently abandoned and opinions are mixed as to whether the town should restore it or demolish it.


19th Street Apartments

Owner: The elusive Mr. Ronald Maddox, a local landlord notorious for neglecting property repairs while still demanding rent on time.
Description: A low-income apartment complex filled with diverse residents. The building is run down, with peeling paint and unreliable plumbing, but it's home for many who can’t afford better housing.


Jackie's East Side Pizza

Owner: Jackie Leone, a friendly, middle-aged man with a deep love for pizza (even if he cannot eat it himself due to lactose intolerance). He’s known for giving free slices to kids who can't afford them in exchange for odd jobs (washing dishes, cleaning, etc.).
Description: Known for its greasy, but delicious pizza, Jackie’s East Side Pizza is a local favorite for a quick bite. The interior is simple and clean, with checkered tablecloths and neon signs that have seen better days.


Dominick's Grocery

Owner: Dominick Santoro
Description: The largest grocery store in the region, it is a family owned store with shelves that are always stocked with local produce and staples. Dominick's caught between the norms of a simpler time and the pull of the modern world. In a struggle to stave off outside commercial interests, the pull of the modern is winning.


Cobblers & Threads

Owner: Betty Whitehall, a no-nonsense seamstress, and her brother Frank Whitehall, the cobbler. They’ve run the shop together for decades, known for their efficient teamwork.
Description: A dual-purpose shop offering both shoe repair and clothing alterations. Known for its fast service, it’s a favorite for residents who want to make their clothes and shoes last a little longer.


Tony’s Barber Shop

Owner: 'Little' Tony McKivett
Description: A classic barber shop where the men of Watashuka gather for haircuts and town gossip. Tony’s father ran the shop before him, and Tony knows just about everyone’s secrets. The shop has old-fashioned leather chairs and a timeless feel.


Nickel Quick-Mart

Owner: Rick Graves, a friendly, overworked man who runs the store mostly on his own. He’s known for always greeting customers with a smile despite the long hours.
Description: A small, rundown convenience store that carries everything from snacks to household items. It’s open late and frequented by everyone in the neighborhood for last-minute purchases.


Metal Circle Apartments

Owner: Martha Hale, a widow who inherited the building from her late husband and struggles to keep it maintained on her own.
Description: A small apartment complex, known for its circular layout which follows what was once the boundary Prairieville. The apartments are affordable but come with frequent maintenance issues. It's popular with students from Caroline College looking for off campus housing.


Anderson's Shady Tree Mechanics and Auto Sales

Owner: Jed Anderson, a gruff but likable mechanic who’s been fixing cars in Watashuka for as long as anyone can remember.
Description: A combination auto repair shop and used car dealership, located just on the road out of town. It’s known for doing quick, cheap repairs and offering used cars at prices that make people suspicious. The junk yard in the fields behind the shop are expansive.


Mid-City Apartments

Owner: Marie Jennings, a tough but fair property manager who tries to do what she can with the limited resources she has.
Description: A crumbling, multi-story apartment building. The elevator is always broken, and the halls are filled with peeling wallpaper. Despite this, it’s always full of tenants; especially the town's aging population who do not have family to stay with.


3 Ball Pawn

Owner: Roy “Three Ball” Smith, a shrewd businessman who claims he can sell anything.
Description: A dark, cramped pawn shop filled with odd trinkets, used electronics, and questionable items. The shop is always busy, with people haggling over prices. It has frequently in trouble with local law enforcement for selling items with a 'questionable' past.


PR’s (Poor Richard’s) Bar

Owner: Richard “Rich” Mulligan, a man whose nickname, Poor Richard, comes from his tendency to drink away his own profits.
Description: A local dive bar with a dimly lit interior, cheap drinks, and live music that is popular with college students.


Cornerstone Center (Community Center)

Manager: Clara Williams, a passionate social worker who does her best to keep the center running with limited funds.
Description: A rundown community center that offers free classes and activities for local kids and adults. The building is in desperate need of repairs, but it’s still a hub for the neighborhood.


Watashuka Chamber of Commerce

Head: Alan Peterson, an optimistic businessman who believes Watashuka’s best days are still ahead, despite the overwhelming evidence to the contrary.
Description: The town’s business association, housed in a small, non-descript building. The Chamber tries to encourage economic development, but the town’s declining fortunes make it an uphill battle.


Peach Street Library

Librarian: Sly Coolstein
The Peach Street Library is the only public library in town. While the number of volumes available are limited, they do cover a wide range of topics not usually found in a rural town library. This is due to the donations of enthusiasts in the region.


Garrison & Sons Law Office

Owner: Jack Garrison and Sons (Ted and Wayne)
Description: A family-run law office, Garrison & Sons handles wills, property disputes, and other local legal matters. Jack is semi-retired, leaving much of the day-to-day work to his sons, Ted and Wayne. The office is a small, simple building with old wooden floors and dusty bookshelves.



Outside the town limits to the Southeast: "Lakeview Shores"
 {Feel: Resort attractions that have seen better days.}
Once a thriving vacation destination, Lakeview Shores has seen better days. Nestled along the edge of Lake "View," this aging resort area was once popular with families seeking outdoor recreation, but a combination of economic decline and neglect has left it in a state of disrepair. The area is now frequented by locals, campers, and the occasional nostalgic visitor, though the glory days are long gone.

Sit n' Eat Diner and Motel

Owner: Doris Larkin, a friendly but world-weary woman in her 60s who runs the place single-handedly.
Description: This diner and attached motel are classic roadside Americana, with faded neon signs and a cracked parking lot. Once a bustling stop for tourists, the rooms are now sparsely occupied, and the diner serves mostly local regulars. Despite the wear and tear, Doris keeps the food hot and the coffee flowing. The motel rooms are clean but dated, with décor that hasn’t been updated since the 1970s.


The Lake (Public House)

Owner: Tom "Big T" Lawson, a burly man in his 50s with a passion for local history and cheap beer.
Description: The Lake is a weathered lakeside tavern that once thrived on summer tourism. Now, it’s mostly filled with locals looking for a cheap drink. The tavern has a large deck overlooking the water, though the view is often shrouded in mist, adding an eerie ambiance. Inside, fishing trophies and old photos of Lakeview’s heyday decorate the walls. Big T is always ready to share stories of the lake’s supposed mysteries, though most patrons dismiss them as drunken ramblings. It is almost never visited by college students and is considered a 'locals only' establishment. "Its the only place in town where a good Lutheran can get a drink."


Lakeside RV Park & Campground

Owner: Marty and Sue Briggs, an aging couple who have managed the site for over 30 years.
Description: The RV park and campground sit on the fringes of Lakeview Shores, offering both short-term and long-term stays. Once a vibrant vacation spot, the campground now attracts a more transient crowd, with only a handful of RVs and tents set up at any given time. The facilities are outdated but functional, and the lake’s shoreline is overgrown with weeds.


All Wet Market & Deli

Owner: Jane and Bob Wheeler, a friendly couple in their late 40s trying to revive the area.
Description: This small market and deli caters to the remaining campers, RV dwellers, and the few vacationers that still trickle in. Despite the area’s decline, Jane and Bob are optimistic and do their best to offer fresh sandwiches and snacks, even though their stock sometimes sits for weeks before being sold. The building is quaint but worn, with a cheery atmosphere inside.


Lakeview Lakeside Fun Center (Mini Golf & Arcade)

Owner: Dave and Cathy Arnold, a laid-back couple in their 50s who refuse to let the place die.
Description: The Lakeview Fun Center was once a bustling family attraction, complete with mini golf, an arcade, and boat rentals. These days, the mini golf course is overgrown, and most of the arcade machines are out of order, save for a few that still function—barely. Dave and Cathy are known for their easygoing attitudes, keeping the place open even if it only gets a few visitors a day.


The Playhouse on the Lake

Owner: Nancy Bright, a former actress who settled down after her career ended.
Description: This small theater once hosted local plays, musicals, and live performances for vacationers. Now, it’s mostly abandoned, with only a few amateur productions each year. Nancy, an eccentric woman with a flair for the dramatic, still dreams of restoring the theater to its former glory, though few share her enthusiasm. The Playhouse is said to be haunted by the ghost of a former actor who died during a performance, but Nancy waves off such rumors with a smile.


The View New Age Shop

Owner: Lucinda "Luce" Moore, a free-spirited woman in her 40s with a deep interest in the supernatural.
Description: This small, quirky shop offers crystals, tarot readings, and other New Age paraphernalia. Luce is one of the few people in Lakeview Shores who embraces the strange energy of the area, and she’s always ready to discuss local legends or offer advice on warding off spirits. The shop is popular with college students and visitors interested in the occult, though locals are often skeptical of Luce’s claims about the lake’s mystical powers. She’s known to host moonlit gatherings by the lake, though only a few daring souls ever attend.



Atmosphere:


Despite its decline, Lakeview Shores holds a certain charm for those who appreciate faded beauty and quiet reflection. The lake, once a source of joy, now seems shrouded in fog and whispers of the unknown. Once a bustling summer retreat, Lakeview Shores has an air of forgotten grandeur. The overgrown paths, weathered motels, and silent campgrounds hint at better days, but now the area feels haunted by time. Despite its decline, Lakeview Shores retains a nostalgic charm for those who remember its heyday.


Lakeview is a working-class neighborhood with a sense of faded optimism. Many of its residents are struggling to make ends meet, and the area’s rundown houses and overgrown lots are signs of its slow decline. Yet, there’s a strong community spirit here, where neighbors help each other out, and children still play in the streets. The boarded-up windows and crumbling facades tell the story of a once-thriving part of town, but the people hold onto hope that better days are coming.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/01-Loca.title: Berg Farm House
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/01-Loca.content:
Berg Farm House

The Berg Watercolor, evidence backing up the claim of the Berg Farm House's history.
History
Records have been lost regarding the origin of the structure known as the "Berg Farm House", but it undisputedly the oldest surviving building in Watashuka. This is based on the "Berg Watercolor". The watercolor has been dated to at least 1876 but historian suspect the painting is much older. From the condition of the building in the painting, and the suggestion of community around the farm house via the existence of other structures (long since lost), the farm is assumed to have been built on or around the 1850's or 1860's.
Current State

The building, which sits on an overgrown lot on 14th street, has survived demolition numerous times in the past decades thanks to the efforts of the Watashuka Historical Society. The rightful owner of the land cannot be determined. The most likely owner, Henry Bergmann, a distant ancestor of the last known Berg family member, claims no ownership. He has actively sought to distance himself, and his family, from the claim. The building is currently abandoned and the Historical Society is attempting to raise funds for renovation and legal work associated with recovering the property.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/01-Loca.title: Frozen Cow
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/01-Loca.content:
The Frozen Cow Burger Stand is a charming, retro 1950s-style diner with a nostalgic flair, located in the heart of Watashuka. Run by Mike and Ruth Garrison, the small, rectangular building is painted in bright red and white stripes, with a large neon sign on the roof that proudly displays the stand's quirky name, "Frozen Cow," in bold, glowing letters. The diner has a few chrome-trimmed windows on the front, offering a peek inside where you can see the grill sizzling and the staff bustling.
The exterior is simple but inviting, with a large awning providing shade for a row of vintage-style picnic tables outside, perfect for customers to enjoy their burgers and milkshakes in the open air. The smell of sizzling beef patties, fresh-cut fries, and sweet milkshakes always wafts through the air, drawing people in.
Inside, the décor is a time capsule of mid-century Americana: red vinyl stools line the stainless-steel counter, and the black-and-white checkered floor gives the place an old-school diner feel. The walls are adorned with framed photos of Watashuka from past decades, along with a few posters of classic cars and rock ‘n’ roll icons. A small jukebox sits in the corner, though it’s often drowned out by the sounds of happy customers and sizzling grills.
Despite its small size, the Frozen Cow Burger Stand is always busy, with lines of locals and college students often extending out the door. It’s known for its simple but delicious menu of burgers, fries, and thick milkshakes, all served with a generous side of nostalgia.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/01-Loca.title: Peach Street Library
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/01-Loca.content:
Peach Street Library
On a quiet Tuesday afternoon, the creaky wooden floors of the Peach Street Library echo with the sound of shuffling footsteps. Sly adjusts his thick glasses, squinting as he scans the shelves, seemingly lost in thought. The faint smell of old paper fills the air as Ronnie bounces from stack to stack, eager to organize a new section of books. A patron walks in, the familiar bell above the door jingling softly. "Looking for something in particular?" Sly asks absentmindedly, not looking up from his pile of reference materials. The library may be old and worn, but its charm and peaceful atmosphere are undeniable.
The Peach Street Library is Watashuka's only public library and has been a quiet cornerstone of the town for decades. Located in an older brick building downtown, the library is a small but cherished institution, offering a modest collection of books ranging from local history to classic literature. Its shelves are packed with aging volumes and dog-eared paperbacks, giving the place a comforting, nostalgic atmosphere. While its resources may not be extensive, the Peach Street Library serves as a peaceful retreat for readers, students, and the occasional researcher looking for information on Watashuka’s history.
The library is run by Sly Coolstein, its head librarian for over thirty years. Despite his often distracted, absent-minded demeanor, Sly knows the library's collection inside and out. He is occasionally assisted by high school student Ronnie Regan, whose enthusiasm for the odd has led to some unusual conversations with patrons from all walks of life. Together, they keep the library running, helping patrons find whatever they need, whether it's a popular novel or a dusty, obscure text.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/01-Loca.title: The Prince-New & Used Books
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/01-Loca.content:
The Prince: New & Used Books is a beloved local bookstore located in the heart of Watashuka, a fixture of the town since the late 1800s. The shop is a cozy and slightly dusty haven for readers and collectors alike, with wooden shelves filled to the brim with both new and rare titles. The shop has a timeless charm, from its creaky wooden floors to the large front windows that let in the warm glow of sunlight, making it an inviting spot for visitors to spend hours browsing the shelves.
One of the shop’s most famous residents is Poe, the small black cat who can usually be found lounging lazily on the counter or curled up in a sunny window. Named after Edgar Allan Poe, the store's mascot is adored by locals and is known for his calm, quiet demeanor, adding to the peaceful atmosphere of the store. Dexter Colby, the current owner, is always ready to recommend a book or help customers find that elusive rare edition.
The Prince is the place to go for literary treasures. Its shelves seem to hold more stories than just what’s in the books themselves, and some regulars say there’s something almost magical about how they always find exactly what they’re looking for, even if they didn’t know they wanted it.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Bernard Miller
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Captain Bernard Miller


Age: 44 (in 1983)


Role: Captain Bernard Miller is the head of the Watashuka Police Department, a position that makes him one of the town’s most prominent figures. He is known around Watashuka for his charm and boasts of romantic escapades, often regaling his colleagues and townsfolk with stories of his supposed conquests. However, he maintains a mostly hands-off leadership style, preferring to let his officers handle the day-to-day operations of the department.


Appearance: Bernard is a ruggedly handsome man with a strong build, which gives him an imposing and confident presence. His neatly styled brown hair and clean-shaven face complement his polished look, adding to his overall image of authority. Bernard’s sharp features and athletic frame make him a figure of attention both in uniform and out. His eyes, however, often carry a subtle, distant sadness, a hint of inner conflict beneath his otherwise composed demeanor. Despite his polished exterior, he tends to carry an air of detachment, especially in moments of quiet reflection.


Personality: Outwardly, Bernard presents himself as confident and charming, playing up his reputation as a womanizer to distract from any suspicions about his private life. He’s known for his laid-back approach to his role, which allows him to maintain his comfortable position without making too many waves. Beneath this, Bernard is a man constantly managing inner turmoil, struggling to balance his public image with the pressures of his personal life.


Public Role:

Watashuka Police Department: As captain of the police force, Bernard is viewed by most as a competent leader, if somewhat distant. He often delegates the bulk of police work to his officers, including more thorough investigations, while he focuses on maintaining order and appearances. His leadership has kept the town functioning smoothly, but his reluctance to confront strange occurrences has led to some tensions within the department, particularly with officers who want to dig deeper into the town’s mysteries.



Relationships:

Sgt. Jan Ducochik: While Bernard respects Jan’s investigative skills, he finds Jan’s obsession with the town’s stranger cases frustrating. Bernard’s desire to avoid conflict often leads him to dismiss Jan’s concerns, especially when they veer into the realm of the unexplained. He sees Jan’s persistence as a threat to the delicate balance he maintains with town leadership.



Public Perception: Watashuka views Bernard as a charismatic, if somewhat complacent, police captain. His reputation as a charming womanizer and hands-off leadership style are well-known, and while some view him as disengaged, most of the town is content with his approach, especially as the town has avoided major incidents—at least, so far.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Dave
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Dave

Name: Unknown (only referred to as "Dave")
Age: Unknown
Role: Dave is the enigmatic, and elusive, pirate radio host of the underground show Metal At Midnight. He hijacks WCTU, Caroline College's AM radio station, for sporadic, late-night broadcasts that combine heavy metal music with wild, conspiracy-laden rants about the government, secret societies, cults, and the supernatural forces lurking in Watashuka. The show starts at exactly midnight and runs until it is abruptly cut off, never airing past 6:14 a.m. Despite multiple attempts by the college and local authorities to trace his signal, no one has successfully uncovered Dave's identity or location.
Personality: Dave is a charismatic and chaotic presence on the airwaves, blending metal anthems with conspiracy theories. His rants are erratic and filled with stoner slang like "bro," "man," and "dude." He jumps between topics with manic energy, often weaving real-world issues with his paranoid theories about government surveillance, cult activity, and the occult. Dave frequently laughs maniacally during his broadcasts and mocks those in positions of power, particularly conservative figures like Mothers Opposing Metal|MOM and the local police.
Beliefs: Dave believes shadowy forces are tracking him, particularly the government and various secret societies. He sees himself as a voice for the oppressed, fighting back against the powers that be by spreading the truth through heavy metal music. He regularly mocks the satanic panic of the era, claiming that the real evil is something far worse, hiding in plain sight within Watashuka.
Appearance: No one knows what Dave looks like. His identity remains a mystery to the authorities, students, and his listeners. Rumors swirl about who Dave might be—some believe he’s a former student or professor, others think he’s an outsider who’s taken up residence on the outskirts of town.
Public Role:

Pirate Radio Host: Dave’s show, Metal At Midnight, has a devoted following among the town’s Metalheads and outcasts. His broadcasts encourage rebellion and defiance against Watashuka’s conservative forces, particularly Mothers Opposing Metal. Through his rants, Dave inadvertently reveals pieces of truth about the town’s occult activity, though listeners must wade through his chaotic monologues to find useful information.
Counterculture Symbol: To many of Watashuka’s younger, more rebellious residents, Dave is a symbol of defiance against the town’s conservative establishment. His show has become a rallying point for the town’s metalheads, who see him as a voice speaking out against the hypocrisy and hidden darkness of the town.


Public Perception: To most of the town, Dave is nothing more than a nuisance, a conspiracy-theorist pirate radio host whose broadcasts are both hard to find and hard to take seriously. While his rants seem like wild paranoia, some of Watashuka’s youth have come to idolize him as a champion of their anti-establishment mindset. Most adults, particularly those in positions of authority, view him as a disruptive force, but they can’t seem to track him down.
Rumors About Dave:

The Ghost Broadcaster: Some say Dave died years ago in a car accident, and his spirit now broadcasts from beyond the grave, using old radio frequencies.
An Old Professor: One theory suggests Dave is a disgruntled former professor from Caroline College, possibly one who dabbled in occult studies.
In League with the Occult: Some residents claim Dave is a Satanist himself, using his broadcasts to send coded messages to his followers.
A Rebel Student: Others believe Dave is a current student, using the college’s equipment to run his show without the administration’s knowledge.
Government Spy: A few conspiracy theorists think Dave is actually an undercover agent for the secret Project Caroline, secretly monitoring the town under the guise of a pirate radio host.
Lives in the Tower: A rumor persists that Dave broadcasts from Qubit Tower, hiding in its unused rooms.
The Forgotten Son: Some believe Dave is the illegitimate child of a prominent family, using his show to exact revenge on the town.
Amish Defector: There’s speculation that Dave fled the local Amish community and now rebels against his former life.
A Dark Ritual Survivor: Some claim Dave was the only survivor of a failed occult ritual in the 1970s and now uses his show to expose the supernatural forces in Watashuka.
A Ho-Chunk Teacher: A rumor that Dave is a member of the Ho-Chunk people who is trying to share secret knowledge.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Dexter Colby
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Dexter Colby
The bell above the door jingles as a customer steps into The Prince. Dexter, with his salt-and-pepper hair neatly combed, looks up from the old novel he’s been reading, offering a subtle smile. "Looking for something in particular?" he asks in his calm, deep voice. He moves gracefully around the shelves, his fingers brushing the spines of books that seem older than the building itself. Dexter may not be the most outgoing shopkeeper, but there’s something about him that makes his quiet bookstore feel like a timeless haven.
Dexter Colby is the owner of The Prince: New & Used Books, a charming, slightly dusty bookstore filled with an eclectic selection of literature. Dexter is known for his vast knowledge of rare and antique books, and his quiet but engaging presence behind the counter. According to local lore, the Colby family has been running the store for generations; arriving shortly after the Great Influx. Dexter often speaks fondly of his ancestors who established the business in the late 1800s. While Dexter can be a bit reclusive, preferring the company of books over people, he’s always willing to help a customer find that perfect read.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Sgt. Jan Ducochik
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Jan Ducochik
Sergeant Jan Ducochik, in his early 30s, cuts an imposing yet composed figure in Watashuka’s police department. Standing tall and well-groomed, Jan’s sharp blue eyes reflect both his intense focus and the quiet burdens he carries. His chiseled face, framed by a thick, well-kept mustache, lends him an air of authority that is only heightened by his neatly pressed police uniform. His dark blonde hair is meticulously combed, and every aspect of his appearance speaks to a man who values discipline and precision. Jan’s build is athletic, with the lean strength of someone who remains physically active and ready for whatever may come his way. There is a seriousness to his demeanor, his sharp gaze constantly observing and assessing his surroundings, as though he’s always alert for something more than the everyday crimes of small-town life.
In the station or on patrol, Jan moves with a purpose that reveals his deep sense of duty. His uniform, spotless and well-fitted, reflects his commitment to his role as a protector of Watashuka. He speaks little but listens intently, giving off a sense of calm, calculated vigilance.

Role: Sergeant Jan Ducochik serves in the Watashuka Police Department. Since joining the force in 1980, he has become a reliable officer, well-liked by the community for his professionalism and dedication. Over the last few years, he has taken a more active interest in the town’s safety, particularly focusing on strange events that others dismiss as coincidences. He has earned a reputation for being diligent, though some colleagues find him overly suspicious.
Age: Early 30s (1983)
Appearance: Jan is a sharp, well-groomed man with striking blue eyes, a chiseled face, and a thick mustache. His dark blonde hair is neatly combed, and his police uniform is always pristine, reflecting his disciplined nature. He has an intense gaze, which locals find reassuring in his position of authority.
Personality: Jan is serious, dutiful, and moral. He is devout in his Catholic faith, though respectful of Watashuka’s predominantly Lutheran traditions. His strict moral code shapes his work, and he often views things in black-and-white terms, always striving to protect the town. However, his more focused approach to uncovering unusual events in Watashuka makes him stand out from his colleagues, some of whom think he is overreacting.
Public Role: Jan is a respected sergeant who actively investigates unusual occurrences around town. His suspicions have led him to dig deeper into strange events, but he presents himself as calm and controlled. He collaborates with the local newspaper editor, Norm Habersham, when needed, gathering tips on town rumors and unexplained occurrences.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Margaret 'Marge' Wilkins
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Margaret Wilkins
Margaret Wilkins, at 66 years old (in 1983), stands behind the counter of her cozy newsstand on the corner of Main Street in Watashuka. Her silver-gray hair is neatly styled in a short, no-nonsense bob, with a few loose strands framing her face. Margaret's sharp brown eyes, still full of keen observation, peer out from behind thick, square-framed glasses, giving her a serious yet approachable look. Her face is lined with years of both worry and laughter, showing the deep creases of someone who has lived a life full of quiet contemplation and unspeakable experiences. She wears a patterned cardigan over a light blouse, a modest but practical outfit fitting for the fall weather. A string of pearls around her neck adds a touch of elegance, a reminder of her former stature as Watashuka's first female senior editor. Her posture is slightly hunched from age, but her hands, still quick and steady, sort through newspapers and magazines with practiced ease. Margaret’s fingers are adorned with a simple gold wedding band, though she was never married—an object of curiosity among the townsfolk.
The newsstand itself is a tight space packed with neatly stacked papers, magazines, and candy bars. The shelves behind her are filled with rows of unsold copies of The Prairie Press, each one a piece of history she refuses to part with. She is a woman who knows far more than she lets on, standing guard over the town’s stories with both caution and care.

Age: 66 (in 1983)
Role: Former journalist and the first female senior editor of The Prairie Press (retired in 1950), Margaret Wilkins is a fixture of Watashuka’s history. She now runs the Press Newsstand in town, selling magazines, newspapers, and small sundries. Despite her seemingly mundane post-retirement life, Margaret’s keen eyes and sharp mind have never dulled.
Background: Margaret began her career as a young and determined journalist in the late 1930s, starting with a pivotal assignment at the age of 22. Her story on the infamous Baptism of '39 was her first major piece for The Prairie, setting the stage for her future career. Margaret went on to cover some of the town’s most notable events during her tenure at the paper, gaining a reputation as a diligent, brave, and sometimes tenacious reporter. She eventually became the first female senior editor of The Prairie Press, a position she held until her retirement in 1950, when she passed the role to Norm Habersham.
Press Newsstand: Since retiring, Margaret runs the small Press Newsstand in downtown Watashuka, quietly observing the town she once wrote about. She’s known for hoarding unsold copies of newspapers, often storing them in the back of her shop. Locals see her as a curious relic of a bygone era, but Margaret continues to follow the news and keeps up with local happenings, even if she no longer writes about them.
Public Perception: To the town, Margaret is a beloved figure from Watashuka’s journalistic past, a pioneer in her field and a woman who stood her ground in a male-dominated profession. Though she no longer engages in investigative journalism, many still remember her early work and come to her newsstand for both gossip and news. She is respected, if occasionally pitied for her reclusive nature.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Max and Maxine McElhenney
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Max and Maxine McElhenney
Max McElhenney
Overview:
Max McElhenney, 19, returned to Watashuka with his twin sister, Maxine, after inheriting their late parents' home. Max enrolled at Caroline College at 18 but put his studies on hold to work as a janitor at the local hospital. With his laid-back demeanor, slow speech, and love of heavy metal, Max is often mistaken for a stoner, a misconception he is quick to correct. He plays drums and frequently jams with Maxine. Despite his carefree appearance, there’s a quiet depth to him that most people overlook.
Public Perception:
Max is viewed by the locals as quiet, if somewhat aloof. His decision to step away from college is seen as "wasting potential," though those who know him at the hospital recognize him as dependable and diligent. His reputation as a metalhead and his easygoing attitude make him popular with the town’s youth, who appreciate his relaxed, nonjudgmental nature.

Maxine McElhenney
Overview:
Maxine McElhenney, also 19, is Max’s twin sister and the more academically inclined of the two. She continues her education at Caroline College, majoring in sociology, while Max works. Though she’s sharp-witted and focused on her studies, Maxine shares her brother’s passion for heavy metal, playing bass guitar alongside him. Maxine is intelligent and driven, but she keeps a certain emotional distance from others, often hiding behind her calm and composed exterior.
Public Perception:
Seen as the more "responsible" twin, Maxine is well-regarded by her professors and peers for her academic achievements. Despite her success, there’s a certain air of aloofness about her—people find her both intriguing and a bit intimidating. Her musical tastes and love for metalheads make her stand out, but she’s never quite fit in with the scene as much as she would like to.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Mike and Ruth Garrison
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Mike and Ruth Garrison

It’s another sunny afternoon at the Frozen Cow Burger Stand. The line stretches down the sidewalk as locals and students eagerly await their favorite meals. Mike stands at the counter, laughing with customers and cracking jokes, his long-ago hippie roots showing in his relaxed demeanor. Ruth, ever the efficient one, works the grill with practiced ease. She glances at Mike, shaking her head with a fond smile. Despite all the hustle, the two seem perfectly in sync, their connection a comforting fixture in the town of Watashuka.
Mike and Ruth Garrison are the proud owners of the Frozen Cow Burger Stand, a beloved 1950s-style diner in Watashuka. Mike, a former hippie who drifted into town in the late 60s, fell in love with Ruth when he stopped at a burger stand where she worked. Mike was lost and in need of a meal. When taking his order, Ruth asked Mike what he was doing in town. Mike said, under the influence, that he was on his way to Alaska. "Why would you want to go way up there?" she asked politely.  “I'm heading up north to check out a free commune.” Ruth misheard him over the noise of the diner - thinking he said he was "heading up north to check out a frozen cow." This was the funniest thing she ever heard and busted out laughing. Mike thought the sound of her laughter was the most beautiful thing he ever heard.
From that moment on, Mike worked hard to buy Ruth her own burger stand. That misunderstanding has become a staple in the community for decades now. And while he gave the drugs up a long time ago, his memory never fully recovered. He readily admits that Ruth is the brains of the outfit.
Mike Garrison is in his early 60s, with a stocky build and a weathered, easygoing face that often carries a big, friendly smile. His thick, silver-gray hair still hints at the carefree days of his youth, and he usually sports a well-worn ball cap or the classic paper diner hat while working at the stand. Mike's style is a blend of practical and nostalgic, often seen wearing a white short-sleeved button-up shirt, tucked into his faded jeans or diner uniform. His voice is warm and booming, quick to share a joke or story from his hippie days, though his past drug use often leads to some comically hazy recollections.
Ruth Garrison is in her late 50s, shorter and more slender than Mike, with neatly styled salt-and-pepper hair often tied back in a simple bun. Her face has a warm yet practical expression, and while she doesn’t smile as often as Mike, when she does, it’s with a quiet, knowing grace. Ruth’s sharp blue eyes seem to notice everything around her, including the details Mike often misses. Her attire is always neat and functional, typically a white blouse beneath a striped apron, making her look like the efficient, hardworking heart of the Frozen Cow. While Ruth is more reserved, she’s also quick-witted and known for her dry sense of humor, especially when it comes to teasing Mike.
Together, they’re a contrasting but complementary pair—Mike, the talkative charmer, and Ruth, the quiet but sharp backbone of the operation.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Norm Habersham
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Norm Habersham
Norm Habersham, now in his early-60s, stands at the editorial desk of The Prairie Press, a figure both familiar and respected in Watashuka. His graying hair is neatly combed, though thinning on top, and his face bears the wrinkles of a life spent both in service and in thought. His sharp blue eyes, which once scanned the horizon as a Navy sailor, now focus intently on the papers and notes before him, always keen and observant. His serious expression give him the look of a man who has seen more than he lets on. Norm is dressed simply, wearing a button-down shirt with short sleeves, the look of someone who values practicality. His well-worn brown slacks show the signs of a man who has spent years in the field. His once-strong frame has diminished with age, but there is still a sense of purpose in the way he carries himself. A wristwatch and a leather notebook always seem to be at hand, tools of a journalist who is ever ready to document a story.
*Behind Norm is the cluttered office of The Prairie Press, where stacks of newspapers and files lie in organized chaos. The atmosphere is one of quiet focus, much like Norm himself—calm, thoughtful, and always working, whether it’s on the next headline or a small-town mystery.

Age: 61 (in 1983)
Role: Norm Habersham is the senior editor of The Prairie Press, Watashuka's local newspaper. A WWII Navy veteran, Norm returned to his hometown after the war and dedicated himself to journalism. He has been at The Prairie for over 30 years, gaining a reputation as a reliable and steadfast figure in the town’s media landscape. Norm is highly respected for his thorough reporting, calm demeanor, and no-nonsense approach to both journalism and life.
Public Career: Over the decades, Norm has covered countless events, both big and small. His dedication to documenting the town’s history, from civic improvements to local tragedies, has made him an integral part of Watashuka’s fabric. He succeeded Margaret Wilkins as senior editor in 1950 and has carried on the paper’s legacy with diligence. Norm’s focus is primarily on local news, keeping residents informed about school board meetings, town hall decisions, and community events.
Key Events Covered:

The Cold Flames at Stratton Mill (1955): Norm was one of the first on the scene after the historic Stratton Mill burned down in a mysterious cold fire. Official reports attribute the blaze to a malfunction in the mill’s equipment, but Norm’s careful documentation of eyewitness accounts—mentioning ghostly flames that neither spread nor consumed—has left some readers puzzled to this day.
Destruction of South High School (1971): South High School’s destruction in a boiler explosion shook the town. The official story points to students tampering with the boiler after a heated basketball game against Delavan High School, but Norm’s in-depth investigation at the time raised questions about unusual circumstances surrounding the incident.
The Parade Storm (1959): A freak storm hit Watashuka during a summer parade, injuring several attendees. Norm reported on the suddenness of the storm and the way it seemed to focus on the parade route. Witnesses spoke of strange winds and a sensation of being watched, though Norm’s article stuck to the basics, leaving the oddities out of print.
The Harvest Moon Disappearance (1967): A local farmer vanished without a trace during the annual Harvest Moon Festival. Norm’s story was the first to suggest that his disappearance might be linked to strange symbols found on his land—a detail the police chose not to publicize.


Public Perception: Norm is widely seen as the last of the old guard in Watashuka. To the townspeople, he is a fixture of the community—someone who has always been around and who is trusted to get the facts straight. He is known for being reliable, discreet, and composed, even in the face of strange occurrences. Many see him as the voice of reason, especially when bizarre rumors circulate through town.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Ronnie Regan
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Ronnie "Moonglow" Regan
As the afternoon sun filters through the dusty windows of the Peach Street Library, Ronnie hums softly to herself while shelving a stack of books. Her fingers trace over the spines of old volumes as if they hold untold secrets waiting to be discovered. She pushes her glasses up her nose, curls falling across her face as she eagerly flips through a dusty tome of local legends. "Have you ever heard of the Cold Flames at Stratton Mill?" she asks Sly, her green eyes lighting up with curiosity. It's clear that Ronnie's passion for the unknown runs deep, and those who know her find it hard not to get caught up in her excitement.
Role/Title: Assistant Librarian at Peach Street Library, Junior at North High School
Description: Ronnie Regan, a 17-year-old junior at North High School, has a vibrant personality and an infectious curiosity about the world, especially the mysteries hidden within it. With her cascade of curly red hair and her round glasses, Ronnie is known for her distinctive thrift-store style, inspired by her parents' hippie past. She spends most of her free time volunteering at the Peach Street Library, assisting the head librarian, Sly Coolstein, in organizing books and cataloging old manuscripts. Though young, Ronnie is already becoming somewhat of a local expert on Watashuka’s folklore, thanks to her boundless enthusiasm for the occult.

01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.title: Sly Coolstein
01-Caroline-College/04-Watashuka/02-Peop.content:
Sly Coolstein
On any given day, Sly can be found behind the library’s main desk, surrounded by stacks of old books and the faint smell of aging paper. He adjusts his glasses and peers at an ancient tome, engrossed in its contents, oblivious to the children giggling behind him as they whisper yet another teasing nickname. One of the kids calls out, "Hey, Sly Foolstein!" He mumbles something incomprehensible under his breath but doesn’t look up. He’s too deep into a translation of an obscure 15th-century manuscript to care. Ronnie, his bright-eyed assistant, pokes her head out from between the shelves and gives him a grin. She knows Sly’s mind is a maze of ancient knowledge, and though she tries her best to keep up, she’s content to let him get lost in his books.
Description: Sly Coolstein, the head librarian of Watashuka’s Peach Street Library, has been a fixture in the town for decades. With thinning gray hair, large round glasses, and a perpetually ink-stained vest, Sly is the picture of a bookish recluse. His unassuming nature and deep knowledge of obscure literature make him a quiet, though essential, part of the community. Despite his awkward demeanor and forgettable appearance, Sly is always willing to help those who share his love for books and history.

01-Caroline-College/05-Factions/Amish.title: Amish
01-Caroline-College/05-Factions/Amish.content:
Amish Community


Overview:
The Amish in the Watashuka region are known for their simple, agrarian lifestyle, adhering to traditional values and shunning modern technology. They live in close-knit, self-sufficient communities and are largely seen as peaceful, humble farmers who avoid interacting with the outside world except for essential trade and commerce. To the people of Watashuka, the Amish represent a way of life removed from the complexities of modern society, focused on faith, family, and farming.


History in the Region:
The Amish first arrived in the Watashuka region in the late 19th century, following the destruction of Prairieville Academy in 1860. Drawn to the fertile farmlands and the opportunity to live a quiet, devout life, the Amish settlers established their community on the outskirts of town. Their migration to the region was seen as part of a broader movement of Amish groups across the Midwest, seeking isolated areas where they could practice their faith and maintain their traditional ways without interference from modern society.
The Amish quickly became a respected part of the community, known for their hardworking nature and their ability to produce high-quality agricultural goods. Over the years, they have maintained their cultural and religious identity, staying separate from most of Watashuka’s daily life, though their presence at local markets and interactions with the townspeople have remained constant. Their farms, with their iconic horse-drawn buggies and simple wooden houses, have become a familiar sight in the area, adding to the rural character of the region.
Despite their isolation, the Amish have seen the area change drastically around them, especially with the expansion of Caroline College and the growing influence of modern technology in Watashuka. While they have largely avoided getting involved in the town’s political or social issues, their commitment to their way of life remains steadfast.


Public Role:
